message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The smooth, bony hard, unilobular, and midline location of the mass suggested Torus palatinus. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma will be painful and tender, while necrotizing sialometaplasia and nasopalatine duct cyst will present with ulceration and discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a hard, smooth, bony mass in the midline of her hard palate, which is consistent with Torus palatinus. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma would have a different presentation and would require a biopsy for confirmation. Necrotizing sialometaplasia and nasopalatine duct cyst would present differently and have different causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass, location, and lack of other significant findings point towards the diagnosis of torus palatinus. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma would present with a slow-growing mass on one side of the palate with pain or tenderness. Necrotizing sialometaplasia would present with a painful ulcer that can mimic a malignancy. Nasopalatine duct cyst would present with a midline swelling in the anterior hard palate but is softer and fluctuant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass as unilobular, bony hard, and in the midline of the hard palate suggests Torus palatinus, a benign bony growth typically found on the midline of the hard palate. The other options do not fit this description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The smooth, bony, hard, non-tender mass in the midline of the hard palate suggests the most likely diagnosis is Torus palatinus. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma would present as a soft tissue mass, while necrotizing sialometaplasia would present as an ulcer. Nasopalatine duct cyst could also present as a midline swelling but would not be as bony hard as Torus palatinus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swelling in the midline of the hard palate without tenderness or lymphadenopathy suggests a Torus palatinus. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma usually presents with slow-growing painless mass, but it is not bony hard. Necrotizing sialometaplasia presents with ulceration and pain, and nasopalatine duct cyst presents as a fluctuant mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and description of the mass suggest that it’s a torus palatinus, a bony growth on the hard palate. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma can present as a smooth, slow-growing mass but it’s usually not hard. Necrotizing sialometaplasia is a benign reactive process that causes ulceration and necrosis of salivary gland tissue. Nasopalatine duct cyst presents as a midline cystic mass on radiographs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swelling is smooth, bony hard, and unilobular, which are characteristic of Torus Palatinus. Palatal pleomorphic adenoma usually presents as a painless mass on the palate with a firm or hard consistency. Necrotizing sialometaplasia is a benign self-limiting oral lesion that presents with ulceration and is usually accompanied by pain. Nasopalatine duct cyst presents as a fluctuant mass at the junction of the hard and soft palate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swelling in the midline of the hard palate is consistent with Torus palatinus, which is a common, benign bony growth. The other options are less likely given the patient's presentation and exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swelling that the patient describes is consistent with Torus palatinus, which is a common, benign bony growth on the hard palate. Palatal pleomorphic adenomas typically present as a freely moveable mass, while necrotizing sialometaplasia presents as an ulceration of the palate. Nasopalatine duct cysts usually present as a fluctuant mass in the midline of the palate.
